author: CNN
title: Massive California waves injure onlookers, bring flooding and treacherous beach conditions to West Coast
text:
Massive California waves injure onlookers, bring flooding and treacherous beach conditions to West Coast
Dec 29, 2023, 6:14 AM
(Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times/Getty Images)
LOS ANGELES (CNN) ‚Äî A powerful offshore storm is
driving towering waves into the California coastline, triggering flooding and warnings of dangerous and damaging swells after several people were injured by a wave along Ventura Beach on Thursday.
The wave crashed over a barrier along the southern California beach, tossing a wall of fast-moving water at a group of onlookers who rushed to escape the deluge, witness video shows. Seawater quickly knocked some people off their feet and pummeled cars as drivers tried to speed away.
Nearly 20 people were briefly swept away in the incident and eight people were taken to the hospital, Ventura officials said.
[#HighSurf]‚Äì Watch when a rogue wave hits the beach at the end of Seward Ave in the City of Ventura. This occurred during the high surf advisory at high tide. Because of this wave eight people were transported to local hospitals. Currently the beaches are closed in Ventura County‚Ä¶ [pic.twitter.com/VlRlgRLhpn]
‚Äî VCFD PIO (@VCFD_PIO)
[December 29, 2023]
High water and dangerous rip currents will churn along some of California‚Äôs beaches through the weekend as much of the West coast ‚Äì spanning from the U.S.-Mexico border to southern Oregon ‚Äì is under coastal flood and high-surf alerts, the National Weather Service said.
Waves as high as telephone poles ‚Äì about 40 feet ‚Äì could slam into San Francisco through Friday morning. Fifteen to 20-foot waves are expected along the central coast.
The dangerous conditions pose an ‚Äúexceptional risk‚Äù of ocean drowning and damage to structures like piers and jetties, the National Weather Service said.
The spectacular waters have enthralled some surfers and onlookers, but weather officials are cautioning that the waves and strong rip tides can be perilous for those nearby.
‚ÄúLarge breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore,‚Äù the National Weather Service warned.
At least one fisherman fell overboard in a harbor off Oxnard and later came ashore uninjured, the Ventura County Fire Department said.
The conditions have already caused some road closures and evacuations in coastal California communities and prompted the rescue of five campers along the San Luis Obispo coast.
Crews in Ventura worked through the night to reinforce a mile-long sand barrier that was damaged by powerful waters on Thursday, the local fire department said. Standing about seven feet tall, the raised wall helps protect beachside communities.
üö® Due to a high tidal surge, numerous closures are in place today. Pls exercise extreme caution near the ocean and stay safe. Here are some views from the Rio Del Mar Esplanade and Seacliff St. Beach. Remember to respect the closures and avoid these areas for your own safety.
[pic.twitter.com/KpNHy4MNC5]
‚Äî CHP Santa Cruz (@CHPscrz)
[December 28, 2023]
Hoping to discourage spectators, local officials closed a main access point to Ventura Pier, which saw a swell of about 20 feet on Thursday. Some coastal streets in the area have also been closed as a precaution.
In central California‚Äôs Santa Cruz, the sheriff‚Äôs office
issued an evacuation warning for some areas on Thursday, which included areas of Rio Del Mar, where seawater filled beachside roadways and pushed against some homes, CNN affiliate KION reported. The warnings were lifted later in the day.
The most extreme impacts were expected along the central and Ventura County coasts, along with Hermosa, Manhattan and Palos Verdes beaches, the weather service in Los Angeles said Thursday.
Tempestuous waters are also battering Northern California, where the Bay Area could see waves of 28 to 33 feet, the weather service advised.
A high wind alert is also in effect for the Bay Area on Friday as wind gusts of up to 50 mph are expected.
Rainfall is likely to stretch northward from the Bay Area throughout the day Friday before shifting south into the weekend.
Massive waves attract surfers to Mavericks
Despite safety warnings, the massive waves are a welcome sight to surfers hungry to tackle the legendary swells at Mavericks Beach, about 25 miles south of San Francisco.
Pro surfers and spectators flocked to the beach on Thursday for a competition at the site known for having
some of the biggest waves in the world, CNN affiliate KGO reported.
Local resident Ion Banner
told the affiliate that surfers from Brazil, Tahiti and Hawaii were out in the water. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty gnarly, it‚Äôs super big,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúThe waves looked absolutely massive and it was everything that we expected,‚Äù said Miguel Blanco, who told KGO he flew in from Portugal to surf the waves. ‚ÄúIt was really big, I‚Äôd say 40-60 foot waves.‚Äù
Mavericks‚Äô jaw-dropping waves ‚Äì caused by unique underwater rock formations ‚Äì reach their biggest heights in the winter, when big wave surfers from all over the world make pilgrimages to face the swells.
The legendary waves and the surfers who brave them have been the subject of several films and documentaries, including the 2012 biopic ‚ÄúChasing Mavericks‚Äù about American surfer Jay Moriarity‚Äôs journey to surf Mavericks as a teen.
On Thursday, the conditions were prime for surfers like Blanco.
‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs your turn, you just gotta go,‚Äù Blanco said. ‚ÄúWhen you see a big wave, you‚Äôre kinda scared but at the same time you‚Äôre feeling like you should go and you just go and enjoy the ride.‚Äù
CNN‚Äôs David Williams contributed to this report.

author: Anonym
title: Conditions for President Tebboune's visit to France are not met, says Algeria - Teller Report
text: Conditions for President Tebboune's visit to France are not met, says Algeria Algerian President Abdelmajid Tebboune's state visit to France has already been postponed twice to 2023. It was supposed to take place in early 2024, but it "is still being prepared," Algerian Foreign Minister Ahmed Attaf said on December 27. Algiers still finds that the conditions for carrying out this visit are not met. This depends on the resolution of five major issues that are still being debated. Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune in Algiers on August 27, 2022. (Illustrative photo) AFP - LUDOVIC MARIN By: RFI Follow Advertising Read More This visit was supposed to confirm the improvement between the two countries, after many diplomatic crises. But the conditions are still not met, and Algiers is making it clear this time through its foreign minister, Ahmed Attaf. The latter affirmed this in an interview given on Wednesday evening 27 December to the podcast platform Atheer, owned by the Qatari channel Al-Jazeera. "We have not reached agreements on five major and heavy issues," said the Algerian foreign minister, who added, however, that work continues and that visits between officials of the two countries are continuing. Among these pending files is the one on French nuclear tests in the Algerian Sahara. France carried out 17 of them between 1960 and 1966 at the Reggane site, then at In Ekker. Documents declassified in 2013 spoke of significant radioactive effects that spread from West Africa to southern Europe. Algeria is asking for "recognition of the damage it has suffered as a result of its tests", as well as compensation. Also, France still refuses, according to Algiers, to hand over the sword and burnous of Emir Abdelkader, arguing the need for a law, says the Algerian diplomat. However, according to the programme of the visit, President Tebboune was to go to the castle of Ambroise, where Abdelkader was imprisoned. The other two files concern mobility and visa issues between the two countries, as well as economic cooperation. title: √Ñltester Marathonl√§ufer der Welt stirbt bei Verkehrsunfall - er trug kuriosen Spitznamen
text:
√Ñltester Marathonl√§ufer der Welt stirbt bei Verkehrsunfall ‚Äì er trug kuriosen Spitznamen
Fauja Singh eroberte als ‚ÄûTurban-Tornado‚Äú die Laufwelt und vollendete noch mit 100 Jahren einen Marathon. Die Legende wurde jetzt Opfer eines tragischen Unfalls.
Bias ‚Äì Eine Lauflegende ist f√ºr immer verstummt. Der als √§ltester Marathonl√§ufer der Welt geltende Fauja Singh verstarb im Alter von 114 Jahren bei einem tragischen Verkehrsunfall in seinem indischen Heimatdorf. Ein Leben voller au√üergew√∂hnlicher Rekorde und inspirierender Geschichten fand ein j√§hes Ende.
√Ñltester Marathonl√§ufer der Welt stirbt bei Verkehrsunfall ‚Äì er wurde ‚ÄûTorpedo Turban‚Äú genannt
Der geb√ºrtige Inder, der unter dem kuriosen Spitznamen ‚ÄûTurban-Tornado‚Äú internationale Ber√ºhmtheit erlangte, wurde am Montag beim √úberqueren einer Stra√üe in Bias im Distrikt Jalandhar von einem nicht identifizierten Fahrzeug erfasst. Nach Angaben indischer Medien erlitt Singh eine schwere Kopfverletzung und erlag am Montagabend seinen Verletzungen im Krankenhaus.
Fauja Singh wurde nach Angaben seiner Familie am 1. April 1911 im indischen Bundesstaat Punjab geboren ‚Äì ein offizieller Nachweis seiner Geburt existierte jedoch nicht. Diese fehlende Dokumentation f√ºhrte sp√§ter dazu, dass seine beeindruckenden Laufleistungen nicht ins Guinnessbuch der Rekorde aufgenommen wurden.
Marathon-Legende Fauja Singh begann Laufkarriere erst mit 89 Jahren
Seine au√üergew√∂hnliche Laufkarriere begann erst im hohen Alter von 89 Jahren. Nach dem Tod seiner Ehefrau und eines Sohnes √ºbersiedelte Singh im Alter von 84 Jahren nach England. Dort inspirierten ihn Marathonl√§ufe im Fernsehen dazu, selbst mit dem Laufen zu beginnen. Was als Bew√§ltigung pers√∂nlicher Trauer begann, entwickelte sich zu einer der bemerkenswertesten Sportkarrieren der Geschichte.
Mit seinem charakteristischen langen wei√üen Bart und dem markanten Turban war Singh bei internationalen Wettk√§mpfen stets ein Blickfang. Seinen Spitznamen ‚ÄûTurban-Tornado‚Äú verdankte er seiner beeindruckenden Geschwindigkeit trotz seines hohen Alters.
‚ÄûTurban-Tornado‚Äú wird zur internationalen Lauflegende
Den H√∂hepunkt seiner Karriere erreichte Singh 2011, als er im Alter von 100 Jahren in Toronto einen kompletten Marathon absolvierte. Die 42,195 Kilometer bew√§ltigte er in acht Stunden und elf Minuten ‚Äì eine Leistung, die ihn zum √§ltesten Menschen machte, der jemals diese Distanz gelaufen war.
Singh wurde zu einer internationalen Ikone des Sports. 2004 trug er das Olympische Feuer in Athen und wiederholte diese Ehre 2012 bei den Olympischen Spielen in London. Er drehte Werbespots mit Weltstars wie David Beckham und Muhammad Ali und wurde zu einem Symbol f√ºr Ausdauer und Lebensfreude im hohen Alter.
Seinen letzten offiziellen Wettkampf bestritt Singh 2013 in Hongkong im Alter von 101 Jahren. √úber zehn Kilometer erreichte er das Ziel in einer Zeit von einer Stunde, 32 Minuten und 28 Sekunden.
√Ñltester Marathonl√§ufer der Welt stirbt bei Verkehrsunfall ‚Äì Trauer um eine Sportlegende
‚ÄûMein Turban-Tornado ist nicht mehr‚Äú, schrieb sein Biograf Khushwant Singh auf der Plattform X und teilte mit gro√üer Trauer den Tod seines engen Freundes mit. ‚ÄûEr wurde von einem nicht identifizierten Fahrzeug erfasst, als er die Stra√üe √ºberquerte. Ruhe in Frieden, mein lieber Fauja.‚Äú
Auch Indiens Premierminister Narendra Modi w√ºrdigte den Verstorbenen in den sozialen Netzwerken. ‚ÄûEr war ein au√üergew√∂hnlicher Athlet mit unglaublicher Entschlossenheit‚Äú, schrieb Modi und lobte die ‚Äûeinzigartige Pers√∂nlichkeit‚Äú von Singh und die Art und Weise, ‚Äûwie er die Jugend Indiens f√ºr ein sehr wichtiges Thema der Fitness begeisterte‚Äú. author: Phil Taylor
title: AZ bags first approval for PNH therapy danicopan, in Japan | pharmaphorum
text: AZ bags first approval for PNH therapy danicopan, in Japan AstraZeneca has claimed its first regulatory approval for oral Factor D inhibitor danicopan, getting a green light in Japan for the drug as Voydeya for the treatment of paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria (PNH). Voydeya is the first drug in the class to be cleared for marketing anywhere in the world and has been licensed for use as an add-on therapy to C5 inhibitors, like its own Soliris (eculizumab) and Ultomiris (ravulizumab) products, in patients who don‚Äôt get a satisfactory response from C5 drugs alone. In PNH, the body‚Äôs complement system destroys red blood cells, leading to anaemia and fatigue and, in some cases, patients need regular blood transfusions. It responds well to C5 inhibitor treatment, but in some cases treatment with C5 drugs can result in changes to red blood cells that mark them for destruction, leading to continued symptoms of anaemia and transfusions. Danicopan was developed to help the approximately 10% to 20% of patients with PNH who experience this extravascular haemolysis (EVH) ‚Äì a breakdown of red blood cells in the spleen, bone marrow, or liver. AZ acquired rights to danicopan as part of its $39 billion acquisition of Alexion in 2021, which also gave it Soliris and Ultomiris, and the drug is viewed as a way to shore up the PNH franchise as it faces competition from new entrants into the category. Those include Novartis‚Äô oral targeted factor B inhibitor [Fabhalta](https://pharmaphorum.com/news/novartis-fabhalta-first-fda-cleared-oral-therapy-pnh) (iptacopan), Apellis‚Äô C3 inhibitor [Empaveli](https://pharmaphorum.com/news/eu-gives-narrower-label-to-apellis-sobis-pnh-drug) (pegcetacoplan), given by subcutaneous infusion, and Roche‚Äôs subcutaneous C5 candidate [crovalimab](https://pharmaphorum.com/news/fda-starts-review-roches-pnh-drug-crovalimab). Soliris, meanwhile, is due to lose patent protection from next year. In the first nine months of this year, AZ reported sales of Soliris were down 15% at constant exchange rates to $2.43 billion, with Ultomiris growing 58% to $2.14 billion thanks to its reduced dosing frequency. Voydeya‚Äôs approval by the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) is based on the results of the ALPHA phase 3 trial, which found sustained improvements in haemoglobin levels and reduced markers of red blood cell destruction over a 48-week follow-up period. ‚ÄúMore than 20 years of PNH research has cemented the role of C5 inhibition in effectively treating this rare disease, and we continue to innovate for this community,‚Äù remarked Marc Dunoyer, chief executive of Alexion. ‚ÄúVoydeya, as add-on to standard-of-care, is a testament to our determination to address the needs of those impacted by clinically significant EVH without disruption to proven therapy,‚Äù he added. AZ has previously said it expects to hear back from regulators in Europe and the US on danicopan in the first half of this year. It is also being tested in phase 2 for geographic atrophy, a leading cause of vision loss, which could open up a much larger market for the drug.

title: Delincuentes asesinan a dos personas y ciudadanos toman comisaria de Atalaya en Ucayali
text: En respuesta al creciente aumento de la inseguridad en las √∫ltimas semanas, la ciudadan√≠a de Raymondi, distrito ubicado en la provincia de Atalaya, regi√≥n Ucayali, convoc√≥ una marcha que comenz√≥ a las 8:00 a.m. en la Plaza de Armas. La manifestaci√≥n pac√≠fica pronto tom√≥ un giro m√°s dr√°stico, llegando a las inmediaciones de la Fiscal√≠a de la Naci√≥n y la comisar√≠a sectorial de Atalaya. MIRA: [Poder Judicial ratific√≥ 12 meses de prisi√≥n preventiva contra exalcalde de Nueva Requena en Ucayali] Arnaldo Macedo y Willy Torres comentaron para RPP que la poblaci√≥n protest√≥ de manera pac√≠fica frente a la comisar√≠a de Raymondi. No obstante, luego tomaron medidas extremas, prendiendo fuego en los exteriores de las oficinas de la fiscal√≠a e ingresando a las instalaciones a la fuerza. ¬øPor qu√© los ciudadanos tomaron la comisar√≠a? Los pobladores explicaron que su protesta se debe a la situaci√≥n de inseguridad ciudadana que ha afectado a la regi√≥n. Sostienen que las acciones de las autoridades y la fuerza policial para mantener la seguridad son insuficientes. Las manifestaciones se habr√≠an provocado luego de que cinco delincuentes ingresaron a una tienda de un conocido centro comercial a robar, pero su atrac√≥ termin√≥ con el asesinado de dos personas. Por otra parte, tras el incidente los ciudadanos se comunicaron con la polic√≠a, pero lamentablemente llegaron tarde. Adem√°s, habr√≠an informado a los efectivos que los sujetos huyeron en una camioneta negra con lunas polarizadas, pero no se habr√≠a realizado una investigaci√≥n exhaustiva. Poblaci√≥n pide que el Gobierno Regional tome acciones contra la inseguridad Los residentes de la provincia de Atalaya manifiestan una profunda preocupaci√≥n e indignaci√≥n por el aumento de robos y asesinatos en la regi√≥n. En un llamado p√∫blico, solicitan al Gobierno Regional de Ucayali que tome medidas correctivas y act√∫e de manera contundente contra los delincuentes.

author: Kieran Kelly
title: Rory Stewart: Rishi Sunak called the election because he wants to ‚Äòget out of government‚Äô - LBC
text: [ Ali Miraj ](/radio/presenters/ali-miraj) 10pm - 1am Exclusive Rishi Sunak called the election because he wants to ‚Äòget out of government‚Äô, Rory Stewart suggests 27 June 2024, 22:36 Rishi Sunak may have called the election early because on some level he wants to "get out of government", former Tory minister Rory Stewart has suggested on LBC. Listen to this article Loading audio... Speaking exclusively to [LBC's Iain Dale](/radio/presenters/iain-dale/), Mr Stewart described the Prime Minister's decision to call the election in July as "literally mad". Asked why by Iain, Stewart said: ‚ÄúI think that maybe subconsciously, psychologically [the Conservatives] may want to lose. ‚ÄúI think [Rishi Sunak](/politics/parties/conservatives/rishi-sunak/) called the selection because at some level he wants to get out. [It] didn't make any sense at all, this date. I mean [it's] literally mad.‚Äù ‚ÄúI think with that...Humza Yousaf has just done the same in Scotland, bit worried Emmanuel Macron has done the same in France...that as they begin to run out of ideas and energy, they begin to loathe themselves. ‚ÄúThey become their own undoing.‚Äù Rory Stewart reflects on Rishi Sunak‚Äôs time as PM Mr Sunak called the election five weeks ago, announcing it in the pouring rain outside 10 Downing Street. Read More: [Nigel Farage ‚Äòdismayed‚Äô after Reform UK canvasser ‚Äòfilmed calling Rishi Sunak f g p**i‚Äô](/news/nigel-farage-dismayed-reform-uk-canvasser-filmed-rishi-sunak-insult/) Read More: [Keir Starmer accuses Rishi Sunak of being ‚Äòbullied into action‚Äô over election betting scandal](/news/keir-starmer-accuses-rishi-sunak-bullied-action-election-betting-scandal/) His campaign has been plagued by a series of gaffes, culminating mid-way through after he decided to leave D-Day commemorations early. In the last week, it has emerged that at least five - and possibly as many as 15 - Conservative candidates are being investigated by the Gambling Commission over alleged bets made in relation to the date of the election. Rory Stewart on the 'rotten state' of UK politics Giving his own opinion on Mr Sunak having worked with him, Mr Stewart told LBC: ‚ÄúI thought that he was somebody who was very, very confident in argument. ‚ÄúSo you could see that in the [debate last night.](/news/keir-starmer-accuses-rishi-sunak-bullied-action-election-betting-scandal/) He's very good at arguing. And I as a minister when I was trying to convince him of something, we'd often get in these very long arguments and he's very good at that kind of debating. ‚ÄúBut I never felt that he had the kind of big sense of who he was and where he stood on the really big issues .I wasn't completely convinced on where he stood on Brexit. ‚ÄúI couldn't understand why he endorsed Boris Johnson so quickly, except because he wanted to get a fast track into the cabinet. ‚ÄúIt's very understandable...many other people I joined Parliament with were like that Matt Hancock and Priti Patel had a bit of that going on as well. ‚ÄúI think in a way to survive as Prime Minister, he needed to have a sense of who he was and who his values were. ‚ÄúHis biggest chance. I still think as if he'd come in and said, ‚ÄòI'm distancing myself from Liz Truss, Boris Johnson. I'm going to vote on this privileges committee report. This is a disgrace. This is a new direction. I'm changing things‚Äô. ‚ÄúHe might have had hope in this election.‚Äù

author: Jeremy Baker
title: Amazing Preservation Race set for May 3 at Legacy park | kens5.com
text: SAN ANTONIO ‚Äî Every May for the past 40 years the National Trust for Historic Preservation has celebrated Preservation month. And one of those events in downtown San Antonio aims to teach participants about the heritage, cultures, and ideas that make our city unique, in a fun way. Its called "The Amazing Preservation Race." It is the only race of it's kind in the Alamo City. Teams of four will follow clues and complete challenges as they learn and use knowledge about San Antonio and it's rich history. And the City wants you to participate. Shannon Miller, the Director of Office of Historic Preservation said, "Teams of four adults must follow clues that help them identify historic spots in downtown San Antonio. And then they have to complete either a mental or physical challenge in order to get their passport filled and complete all the challenges and get back to the finish line." And it isn't just for the adults. "It's really intended to help us celebrate and also highlight the the built heritage and the culture and traditions that make San Antonio special," said Miller. The challenges are top secret and spread out across three miles of downtown. Races can use cellphones to decipher clues that are based in San Antonio's history and architecture. You can only use your feet to get around, no public transit or rideshares. Prizes will be awarded to the top three finishers, best costume, and best team spirit. Miller added, "You also have to complete some detours along the way that are not location specific. So it might be taking a photo with a dog or something along those lines that are one of the detour options." And for those that race, it is a two-fer! Miller said, "Amazing preservation race is really a fun way to get people both out in the community being active, but then also just really learning about San Antonio's local history and culture. The race takes place Friday, May 3 at 6:30 p.m. at Legacy Park. People can sign up until Apr. 30.
